Authors: Attanasi F.; Knopf A.; Parodi K.; Paganetti H.; Bortfeld T.; Rosso V.; Guerra A.D.
Title: Extension and validation of an analytical model for in vivo PET verification of proton therapy - A phantom and clinical study
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Pisa, INFN, Pisa, Italy; University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, DE, Germany; Department of Radiation Oncology, Heidelberg Ion Therapy Center, University Clinic of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, DE, Germany; Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Attanasi F., Department of Physics, University of Pisa, INFN, Pisa, Italy; Knopf A., University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, DE, Germany; Parodi K., Department of Radiation Oncology, Heidelberg Ion Therapy Center, University Clinic of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, DE, Germany; Paganetti H., Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, United States; Bortfeld T., Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, United States; Rosso V., Department of Physics, University of Pisa, INFN, Pisa, Italy; Guerra A.D., Department of Physics, University of Pisa, INFN, Pisa, Italy
Abstract: The interest in positron emission tomography (PET) as a tool for treatment verification in proton therapy has become widespread in recent years, and several research groups worldwide are currently investigating the clinical implementation. After the first off-line investigation with a PET/CT scanner at MGH (Boston, USA), attention is now focused on an in-room PET application immediately after treatment in order to also detect shorter-lived isotopes, such as O15 and N13, minimizing isotope washout and avoiding patient repositioning errors. Clinical trials are being conducted by means of commercially available PET systems, and other tests are planned using application-dedicated tomographs. Parallel to the experimental investigation and new hardware development, great interest has been shown in the development of fast procedures to provide feedback regarding the delivered dose from reconstructed PET images. Since the thresholds of inelastic nuclear reactions leading to tissue β+-activation fall within the energy range of 15-20 MeV, the distal activity fall-off is correlated, but not directly matched, to the distal fall-off of the dose distribution. Moreover, the physical interactions leading to β+-activation and energy deposition are of a different nature. All these facts make it essential to further develop accurate and fast methodologies capable of predicting, on the basis of the planned dose distribution, expected PET images to be compared with actual PET measurements, thus providing clinical feedback on the correctness of the dose delivery and of the irradiation field position. The aim of this study has been to validate an analytical model and to implement and evaluate it in a fast and flexible framework able to locally predict such activity distributions directly taking the reference planning CT and planned dose as inputs. The results achieved in this study for phantoms and clinical cases highlighted the potential of the implemented method to predict expected activity distributions with great accuracy. Thus, the analytical model can be used as a powerful substitute method to the sensitive and time-consuming Monte Carlo approach. © 2011 Institute of Physics and Engineering in Medicine.

Authors: Xu Y.
Title: Nuclear energy in China: Contested regimes
Affiliations: Department of Politics and Public Policy, Griffith University, Brisbane, QLD 4111, 170 Kessels Road, Nathan, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Xu Y., Department of Politics and Public Policy, Griffith University, Brisbane, QLD 4111, 170 Kessels Road, Nathan, Australia
Abstract: China is leading the recent revival of nuclear energy programs; it is building not one but four nuclear power plants at a time. The government is determined to expand nuclear energy programs and the general public supports the efforts. China also has the financial and human resources to achieve the desired objective-building 40 GW generation capacity by 2020. The politics surrounding nuclear energy expansion, however, is fluid and competition for influence is vibrant. Nuclear energy issues have become openly contested between general economic and specific industry interests and between international and domestic perspectives and designs. This article examines the political dynamics in China to show how the rival players and their competing interests shape the strategy of nuclear energy development. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: China; Nuclear energy; Nuclear energy policy
Index Keywords: Asia; China; Eurasia; Far East; Electric power plants; Electric utilities; Fluidics; Nuclear energy; Nuclear engineering; Nuclear physics; Nuclear power plants; Planning; Power plants; Strategic planning; Elsevier (CO); Energy expansion; energy programs; General (CO); General Public (CO); Generation capacity; Government IS; Human resources; International (CO); Nuclear energy development; Political dynamics; government relations; human resource; nuclear power; nuclear power plant; power generation; Energy resources
Funding Details: CNNC; China National Nuclear Company; China Power Investment Corporation; China Technology Import and Export Corporations; Guangdong Nuclear Energy Corporation; Ministry of Nuclear Energy in; State Assets Management Commission; State Council; State Council changed the Second Ministry of Machine Building; State Electricity Regulatory Commission; State Environmental Protection Administration; Ministry of Land and Resources of the People's Republic of China; China Atomic Energy Authority; National Development and Reform Commission; Key Laboratory of Engineering Plastics, Chinese Academy of Sciences; National Commission for Science and Technology; Guangdong Power Grid Company
Funding Texts: Since the government expressed its desire to speed up nuclear energy development in the early 2000s, there has been a heated debate in China not about whether but about how to expand. Instead of seeing this debate as an episode independent from the general political development, this paper sees it as an indication of irrevocable and evolving changes in politics in China. Nuclear energy is a politically sensitive topic. Divisions among groups and public opinion can halt or stall a nuclear energy program, as it has been seen in many OECD countries after the Chernobyl disaster. Yet, this could only happen in democratic societies. In China, described by one critic as a “communist autocracy” or “an obscure entity”, “controlled by a secretive camera-shy Politburo” [28] , nuclear policies used to belong to the ‘nuclear sub-government’ or nuclear establishment alone, dominated by secrecy and top–down decision making [29] . Nuclear policies were kept under the tight grip of the Party and their implementation was controlled strictly by the nuclear establishment in charge of both military and civilian nuclear programs. The public had no role to play in the area. Such an explanation of the current nuclear energy expansion clearly oversimplifies the politics of China today. In their classic book on Chinese policy making, Lieberthal and Oksenberg discussed the “fragmented authoritarian” decision-making process [30] . The system was authoritarian because of the control of the Party while decision making was fragmented because authority was divided among the various central ministries and provinces. Fragmentation was overcome by bargaining; decisions were made by consensus; and the policy process was protracted and incremental. In this process, the interests of social groups were articulated not through autonomous interest groups but through bureaucratic organizations. Now many more players are participating in this process. They include newly corporatized large energy companies [8,24,31] , academics [32] , think tanks [33–35] and media. In the energy sector, state-owned companies have increasingly asserted their voice in decision making while the bureaucratic ministries were eliminated or replaced by much smaller agencies. Indeed, no one centralized decision-making body has existed in the energy sector since 1993 when the Ministry of Energy was eliminated. In several sub-sectors, the old ministries were replaced by large state-owned corporations. The State Power Corporation, for example, was created in 1996 to continue the economic functions of the Ministry of Electric Power and it gradually gave up the administrative and regulatory functions to some much smaller institutions [36] . Oil companies were corporatized as well in the 1990s and given considerable autonomous control in making business decisions. They now participate in policy making in their own right [8,37,38] . These political changes in energy policy making are recognized by scholars who have pointed out the barriers that prevent effective management and regulation of the energy sectors in China—“a combination of political opposition, vested interests and ineffective government”, “the inadequate or inappropriate nature of national regulatory regimes” and “a lack of financial resources to implement policies” [38] . Others have drawn the similar conclusion that the recent widespread power shortages and surging oil demands were the result of “ineffective institutions and strong vested interests”: “Poor coordination between the government and the state-owned energy companies have hindered development of a comprehensive national energy strategy” [8] . Few studies, however, have covered the nuclear energy sector, which has long been submerged into military studies. There has been hardly any distinction between military and civilian nuclear development in policy analysis. Yet, in the nuclear energy sector, similar changes have taken place. When China decided to start a nuclear energy program in the 1980s, the State Council changed the Second Ministry of Machine Building, which had built China's first atom bomb, hydrogen bomb and nuclear submarine, to the Ministry of Nuclear Energy in charge of both military and civilian nuclear development. Meanwhile it created China National Nuclear Company, which was in turn incorporated into the CNNC in 1999 and its regulatory functions were granted to the newly created China Atomic Energy Authority (CAEA) under the Commission of Science Technology and Industry for National Defence (CSTIND). CAEA in theory is responsible for (a) drafting policies, regulations and development plans for “peaceful use” of nuclear energy; (b) organizing, approving and supervising nuclear R&D; (c) leading the State Committee of Nuclear Accident Coordination; and (d) representing China in international organizations and international cooperation [39] . In practice, however, CAEA mainly represents China in international arenas and coordinates nuclear emergencies. Other players include the China Guangdong Nuclear Power Company (CGNPC), the NDRC, the Ministry of Land and Resources, the Chinese Academy of Engineering, the State Electricity Regulatory Commission, the State Assets Management Commission, and the State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA). Recently, four major power generation companies have also sought to be part of the game by applying for permission for potential NPP projects. They participate in decision making only when their interests are concerned. The two key players in the recent debates on nuclear energy expansion are CNNC and NDRC. CNNC represents the interests of the nuclear community, while NDRC is a “macroeconomic planner”. CNNC was created in 1988 to be responsible for and remains in charge of both civilian and military nuclear activities at all levels of the nuclear fuel cycle. It now controls most nuclear sector business, including R&D, engineering design, uranium exploration and mining, enrichment, fuel fabrication, reprocessing and waste disposal. CNNC is an industrial conglomerate, consisting of over 100 often quite independent subsidiary enterprises and institutions. Like other major state-owned energy companies, it is a major investor and operator of China's NPPs (7 out of 11). Also like other energy companies, it is accountable directly to the State Council and its president and vice presidents are appointed by the State Council. Therefore, CNNC sees itself the representative of the interests of the nuclear energy sector and the principal voice for the nuclear community in China. With over a quarter of its employees engaging in R&D in various disciplines, CNNC is particularly interested not only in developing new technology but also ensuring the opportunities to adopt the technology in the process of nuclear energy expansion. NDRC originated in the State Planning Commission (SPC), whose name and functions have changed several times throughout the reform. SPC changed to State Planning and Developing Commission in 1998 and then dropped the last vestige of the planning economy, and became the NDRC in 2003 after absorbing some functions from the State Economic and Trade Commission. NDRC is still in charge of drafting the 5-year plans, which nowadays set the direction for, rather than dictate, the coming years’ development. Since no unitary centralized government agency making energy policies has existed since 1993, NDRC has taken as its own responsibility de facto control of the energy sector through its authority to approve major capital projects. When power shortages re-emerged in 2002, there was a call for a centralized agency to coordinate energy policies and ensure energy supplies. Unable to get major energy players (mainly large state-owned energy companies in oil/gas, electricity and coal industries) on board, the State Council created an Energy Bureau under the NDRC [8] . Even though the Energy Bureau does not have adequate manpower to do the work and has no authority over the state-owned energy companies which had grown a life of their own, NDRC claims to be the authority for overall policy for energy security. This authoritative position seemed to be confirmed in 2005 when the government formed the Energy Leading Group (ELG) under the State Council headed by Premier Wen JiaoBao; the Office of the Energy Leading Group was headed by Ma Kai, chairman of the NDRC, reporting directly to the Premier. NDRC, its Energy Bureau and the Office of ELG (serviced by the same group of people) are responsible for formulating development plans for the energy sector, recommending system reform, planning for emergencies, and undertaking research on energy conservation, strategic reserves and exploration. The energy companies control most resources—financial, human and technical. To ensure adequate energy supplies, NDRC advocated a rapid expansion of nuclear generation capacity, partly to diversify energy supplies, partly to show the world that the Chinese government was doing something to address environmental problems, and partly to satisfy the rising energy demand from the coastal provinces. These regions have led economic growth and rising living standards, but they have experienced perennial energy shortages and have limited energy endowments with which to expand their own power generation capacity. In spring, 2006, in a standing committee meeting of the State Council to discuss the draft short- and medium-term energy development (2005–2020), the deputy chairman of NDRC argued that to build 40 GW nuclear generation capacity by 2020 was too low an objective; China needed to speed up the expansion. To do so, NDRC crafted the strategy of “introducing, digesting, absorbing (also known as localizing) and innovating” the advanced and mature technology from overseas. China could then standardize the technology and start building several units simultaneously [40] . It argued this was the way France developed its nuclear energy industry and should be the path China adopted. In addition, as a “macroeconomic management agency”, NDRC “studies and formulates policies for economic and social development, maintains a balance of economic aggregates and guides the overall economic system restructuring” [41] . It needs to consider not only energy development but also other sectors. Balancing economic and social development and demands from external forces is the game it must play. In the past several years, China has been under significant pressure from the US government to change its trade policies and appreciate its currency. The pressure from the US Congress was building up as the Democrat senator from New York, Charles Schumer, and the Republican senator from South Carolina, Lindsey Graham, threatened to introduce a bill to impose an across-the-board tariff on Chinese imports in an effort to reduce China's “unfair undervalued” currency advantage. Thus, dealing with the Americans was another concern when the energy issues were considered. In the nuclear community, however, the perceptions of the challenges were quite different. The policy of “a limited nuclear development” in the 1980s and 1990s not only led to the slow progress of China's nuclear energy program but also a brain drain to other sectors and countries; many universities closed their nuclear science and nuclear engineering programs and the funding on R&D declined significantly. Reviving the industry meant that the policies must change. That is, instead of encouraging development of coal-fired generation capacity, the government should include nuclear energy into the overall energy planning and give it a priority too. According to the Chinese media, however, three different views existed on how to promote nuclear energy expansion: one was to improve the technology (domestic and foreign) China had already adopted; one was to introduce the most advanced technology in the world; and one was to develop and adopt its CNP1000 and CNP1500 [42] . Most people in the nuclear community argued that the government should amend the policy of “introducing foreign capital and technology” [6] and give the resources and opportunities to the people and institutions in the field in China to develop indigenous technology and equipment. CNNC has consistently emphasized “self-reliance, assisted by international cooperation” [13,43] . The government seemed to have agreed with the nuclear community that encouraging indigenous R&D and utilizing local designs and technology were crucial for China's nuclear expansion. In 2002, when visiting the Qinshan II project, Hu Jintao, then vice president of the country, stated that “nuclear energy industry is a strategic industry and China needs to develop its own technology for its expansion. No money can buy the core technology. Developing indigenous design and technology is the only way for nuclear expansion” [44] . This speech was consistent with the spirit of a document issued early in the year by the State Development and Planning Commission (SDPC), the predecessor of the NDRC. The 10th 5-year plan (2001–2005) also outlined the strategy for nuclear energy development of “combining self-reliance with foreign partnership” [45] . As far as CNNC was concerned, relying on the indigenous technology was the official policy and it expected that the new NPP projects would adopt the Chinese designed CNP 600, which was used in Qinshan II and its up-graded versions, such as CNP1000. In 2003, NDRC decided to put the Sanmen and Yangjiang projects up for international bidding. The decision immediately attracted interest from major international nuclear engineering companies that all wanted to get a piece of the pie. Russia put in its bid but quickly withdrew. This left France's Areva Group, the world's biggest nuclear engineering firm with $13.5 billion in sales, and Westinghouse, which had been purchased by the British BNFL in 1999. To the Americans, this meant billions of dollars at stake. From 1996 to the end of 2003, not one company bought a single new reactor on line in US, or cleared a patch of ground to begin building, or applied for a license to start construction. China's market was therefore most attractive. In 2002, the US embassy in Beijing already reported that it believed “about 300 enterprises are engaging in the development and production of nuclear technology in China” [46] . When China put its projects up for international bidding, the US government grabbed the opportunity, doing everything it could to help Westinghouse beat its competitors and win the bid. “The US government began working with the Chinese government to support the bid of a US manufacturing in 2004” [47] . The US Department of Energy reached a cost-sharing agreement with Westinghouse for the AP1000 design, for supporting the completion of Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) design certification and for the NRC licensing and construction of the first standard AP1000 nuclear plant design. The NRC fast-tracked the approval process for the AP1000 specifically, so Westinghouse could participate in the bidding for the Chinese contract. The US Export–Import Bank approved $5 billion in loan guarantees for the Westinghouse bid. Even “Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Secretary of Commerce Carlos Guiterrs contributed support to Westinghouse's bid” [47] . In 2004, when Vice President Cheney visited China, officially to orchestrate a media campaign to condemn North Korea's nuclear program, he spent much of his time in China promoting Westinghouse's new AP1000. To win the deal, the US government increased its pressure by linking this bid with China's trade surplus and currency appreciation. The decision to put Yangjiang and Sanmen up for international bidding caused increasing concerns ever since it was announced. At the core was the issue of which direction China's nuclear energy expansion would take. By the end of 2005, the nuclear community was further alarmed when NDRC formally introduced the 11th 5-year plan (2006–2010), which dropped the phrase of “combining self-reliance with foreign partnership’. In its place, the plan emphasized the importance of adopting the most advanced technology and specified that China would introduce the third-generation reactors from other countries GW by 2010 but retained the 40 GW target for 2020. The decision whether to put development of indigenous technology and equipment or import of foreign technology at the top of the policy priority would affect the whole investment and management structure of the industry and the future of the nuclear community. [48] . The plan also revised the objective from 20 to 12  CNNC, representing the interests of the nuclear community, criticized NDRC for changing the policies agreed upon in 2002—to develop its own design and technology while introducing international advanced technology—and for putting the country's nuclear industry at technical , financial and security risks [10,43] . To support their position, some nuclear scientists in China argued that the Westinghouse AP1000 was not the IAEA-approved third-generation technology; it was not much different from the second-generation design and technology. Instead of spending resources purchasing this technology, the country should use the resources to support the development of the indigenous technology, which was well on its way to developing the third-general reactors. Others argued that even if AP1000 had the most advanced technology and design, not one country had adopted it. If Westinghouse won the bid, China would be the first country to use the technology. There would be no experience to learn from or lessons to draw. Furthermore, even for those who have acknowledged the advantages of the AP1000 in China, the idea that China could duplicate it and expand its nuclear energy capacity quickly was contentious because China's future development would be “controlled” by foreign companies and the market system would never bring about real technology transfer; China needed to develop its own system [49] . The Chinese scientists had been working on their own CNP1000, and it was feared that if the Chinese technology was not given an opportunity to be utilized China would never be able to be independent in nuclear technology. The opposition quoted several similar cases, such as China's automobile industry and its civilian aeroplanes; in both fields, the supporters of foreign design and technology had won and then the Chinese simply did not have the opportunity or support to develop their own. The fields were “granted” to “foreign” companies. In contrast, because US had banned the export of the military jets to China, the Chinese military and scientists had and were able to develop a top quality jet comparable to the products from other countries [50] . Moreover, according to the opposition, the estimated cost for the AP1000 was too high compared to domestic technology. AP1000 was about US$2300/kW and about US $2 billion a piece. The estimated cost for CNP1000 was $1300/kW once it went to standard production, the same cost as CNP600 adopted in Qinshan Phase II MW unit, the cost differential would be at least $1 billion. If all the new NNPs to be built by 2020 used the imported technology, it would mean over US$30 billion extra costs. [13] . This meant that for each 1000 Finally, the opposition was joined by those who raised security concerns [51] . That is, if the bid was won by Westinghouse, China would face political and security risks. After Westinghouse put its bid in for the Sanmen and Yangjiang projects, the Japanese Toshiba beat other well-known companies, such as General Electric and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, to purchase Westinghouse for US$5.4 billion in early 2006. This almost tripled the price the UK-government-owned British Nuclear Fuels had paid when it bought Westinghouse in 1999. The CEO of Toshiba made it clear that it paid a hefty sum for the 100% stake of Westinghouse with the expectation that nuclear power generation would expand quickly, especially in China [52] . This issue became a hot political potato for the Chinese government when the negotiation with Westinghouse was in process. The fear was expressed that giving Westinghouse the contract would mean that the Japanese would enter into the Chinese nuclear market and fulfil its ambition to control Chinese nuclear development. Criticism and opposition could all be heard throughout the debates. They were taken into consideration during the negotiation by the NDRC. The negotiation took so long partly because of the complaints from the nuclear community and partly because of media reports pointing out the potential technical, financial and political risks of awarding the contract to Westinghouse. To satisfy the nuclear community, the Chinese negotiators demanded a full transfer of nuclear technology to local partners. Both the French Areva and Westinghouse were “committed to sharing their technology with the Chinese to clinch deals” [7] . In previous cases, such as Daya Bay and Qinshan Phase III, the foreign manufacturers not only used their technology, design and equipment but also managed the construction. Little technology was transferred even though some insist that by working side by side with multinational corporations China built a team of highly qualified and well-trained people. Eventually, “Westinghouse has agreed to transfer technology to Chinese that could lead to the construction of many more nuclear reactors in China over the next 15–20 years” [53] . The Secretary of US Department of Energy was quoted as saying, at the signing ceremony, that “the Chinese were very demanding; Chairman Ma and the NDRC were very demanding” in securing full technology transfer as a condition for granting the contract [53] . For many in the nuclear community, this statement may not be sufficient to ensure the development of indigenous technology because of their long-held suspicions about the willingness of multinational corporations to share technology. On several occasions they had agreed in the contracts to share the most advanced technology, but by the time the contract became effective the technology was already abandoned by these companies [54] . This view was consistent with that expressed by Hu Jintao and Wen Jiabao: even though the market may work in other sectors, market exchange will not bring in the core technology, which needs its own investment and human capacity. Indeed, in May 2007, the State Council established the State Nuclear Technology Corporation (SNTC). This may be interpreted as an effort to “compensate” the nuclear community. The State Council contributed 60% of the assets of SNTC and the rest came 10% each from CNNC, China Power Investment Corporation, Guangdong Nuclear Energy Corporation, and China Technology Import and Export Corporations. Its creation was part of the overall strategy of the first stage for nuclear expansion (before 2010)—introducing the most advanced, mature and reliable technology embodied currently in the third-generation reactors, monitoring the international R&D and developing its own team of scientists in the field [55] . This might not be exactly what most of the nuclear community had called for (they had wanted to see the creation of a single research institute in the field as in many other countries), but many welcomed it. Whether China should introduce foreign technology or co-operate with multinational corporations was never an issue. Foreign suppliers have always played a significant role in China's nuclear program: the involvement of French technology in making fuel for Qinshan and Daya Bay power plants; the Research Institute for Nuclear Service Operation, a joint venture with Westinghouse; the training in Spain of operators for Qinshan; and the German main cooling pumps and injection pumps at Qinshan, to list just a few. They would push for their interests whenever they could. The alternative views expressed by the nuclear community, therefore, should not be taken as a fundamental challenge to the government and its policies. It was a public debate about how these policies should be pursued and who should benefit from the nuclear energy expansion. In the nuclear sector those who engaged in the debate are ‘insiders’, mainly from CNNC, its subsidiaries and its associates. They have “grown up in the shadow of—and, indeed, inside—the party/state” [1] . Their interests may be different from, but not contradictory to, those of NDRC. This deal shows the complexity of today's politics in China where the government has to juggle with the pressures from all directions:  • Some wanted to see the introduction of the most advanced technology so that they could learn, duplicate and then improve it. • Some did not want to see multinational corporations dominate the Chinese nuclear industry and insisted on indigenously development technology. • Some opposed the deal anyway because Westinghouse had been bought by the Japanese Toshiba that had made clear it had every intention to “expand its global reach”. • Some wanted to use this deal to “help China in its talk with Japan on the East China Sea dispute.” • Some hoped the deal with Westinghouse could appease those in the US Congress so that the tension over trade and currency issues would not escalate. A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed between the US Department of Energy Secretary Samuel W. Bodman and the Chairman of NDRC in December 2006. Westinghouse would construct four NPPs, two at each site—Sanmen and Yangjiang. The deal was worth more than $5 billion and could lead to as many as 5500 jobs in 12 US states. The Americans agreed on a full transfer of technology and also accepted China as a partner in the development of the Generation IV nuclear reactor [53] . Chinese nuclear scientists and engineers will be given the opportunities to participate in the construction. CNNC hopes to use the imported plant design to develop its own version of the technology, which could prepare it for a greater role in the next round of expansion after 2012. Widening constituencies, especially the four major power generation companies, have joined the game as the nuclear energy program expands. Their interests are not exactly the same as those of the nuclear community. In general, they support the use of more advanced and mature foreign technology because they wanted to have modern and safe NPPs to provide a reliable electricity supply as soon as possible. Their objective is to generate profit by selling electricity. At a time of widespread power shortages, any additional generation capacity is welcome. The nuclear community complained that the power companies made huge profits without being willing to share in nuclear R&D. Those who were concerned about the possible tariff increases by the US government also supported the deal, arguing that awarding the contract to Westinghouse might ease trade pressures from the US. Some in the nuclear community argued that getting access to US technology, which China did not have, would play a positive role in its own technological development [56] . In this whole process, little discussion on other issues, such as the locations of NPPs, potential risks or waste management, surfaced. The public in general remained silent on the issue, leaving discussion to the professionals, but not because of the traditional secrecy or the potential repression on their opposition. The Institute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology, Qinghua University, even conducted surveys between 2002 and 2006 on public opinion toward nuclear energy expansion. It showed about 80% of people surveyed supported nuclear energy expansion; the rate of support was higher in 2004–2006 than in the first 2 years. Another survey conducted at the same time showed that over 76% of the people had only heard of nuclear energy in general terms and had no other knowledge. Their support for nuclear expansion is currently based on a different set of beliefs from OECD countries where lack of knowledge about nuclear energy is often seen as the key to the opposition to nuclear development and where the issue is debated with emotion rather than rationality. The seeming consensus on nuclear energy expansion in China can be explained by the widespread concerns about environmental pollution and energy shortages. Improving environmental conditions and providing adequate electricity supplies are more pressing challenges than fear of nuclear disaster [49] . Moreover, since the country started its nuclear energy program relatively late, nuclear waste is not a major concern yet. The technology used is relatively new and none of the NPPs is near recommission. The consensus for nuclear energy expansion, however, does not necessarily translate into a support for specific nuclear projects and their locations. Like many other countries with nuclear energy projects, when asked about whether they would support a NPP in their own region, less than 50% of the people in China gave a positive answer. Study after study has shown that public education about nuclear technology does not change public opinion easily. This can be problematic for the Chinese nuclear program, particularly with the development of information technology. As it was reported recently, “information technology in China is once again making political waves” [57] . As the country develops, the middle class expands and information technology is widely used to mobilize the public and media. The recent scandal over slave labor and the location of the Taiwanese-owned paraxylene plant were both exposed by people sending messages on their mobile phones. The mobile phone messages eventually organized protests attended by civil servants and ordinary people without prior approval from the government. It is conceivable that, one day, people could be organized in this way to raise their existing concerns over NPP projects and to develop strong opposition. Politics is no longer the same in China and public opinion can no longer be totally ignored. 4

Authors: Pavlenko V.I.; Cherkashina N.I.; Yastrebinsky R.N.
Author full names: Pavlenko, V.I. (24780048400); Cherkashina, N.I. (55776413700); Yastrebinsky, R.N. (25722454200)
Title: Synthesis and radiation shielding properties of polyimide/Bi                         2                         O                         3                          composites
Affiliations: Institute of Chemical Technology, Radiation Monitoring Laboratory, Belgorod State Technological University Named After V.G. Shoukhov, Kostyukov str., 46, Belgorod, 308012, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Pavlenko V.I., Institute of Chemical Technology, Radiation Monitoring Laboratory, Belgorod State Technological University Named After V.G. Shoukhov, Kostyukov str., 46, Belgorod, 308012, Russian Federation; Cherkashina N.I., Institute of Chemical Technology, Radiation Monitoring Laboratory, Belgorod State Technological University Named After V.G. Shoukhov, Kostyukov str., 46, Belgorod, 308012, Russian Federation; Yastrebinsky R.N., Institute of Chemical Technology, Radiation Monitoring Laboratory, Belgorod State Technological University Named After V.G. Shoukhov, Kostyukov str., 46, Belgorod, 308012, Russian Federation
Abstract: Radiation shielding composites based on polyimide and Bi                             2                             O                             3                              were synthesized. Surface and physical-mechanical properties of polyimide/Bi                             2                             O                             3                              composites were studied. Bi                             2                             O                             3                              particles were modified by polymethylphenylsiloxane for the uniform distribution of filler in composites. This paper presents data on the production of composites in two ways: hot- and cold-pressing. The hot-pressing method for the synthesis of composites is preferable compared to the cold-pressing method (the density increases by 10–12%, and the Vickers microhardness by 10–20%). The results show that the introduction of Bi                             2                             O                             3                              significantly increases the thermal stability of the composites. At 680 °C, a polymer composite containing 10 wt% Bi                             2                             O                             3                              retains 9.7% of its mass, and at 60 wt% Bi                             2                             O                             3                             , retains 58.4%. The radiation-protective characteristics of the composites with respect to gamma radiation were evaluated by experimental and theoretical methods. High radiation-protective characteristics of the composites have been established in the gamma-quanta energy range of 0.1–1 MeV.                          © 2019
Author Keywords: Condensed matter physics; Materials science; Nuclear engineering
Funding Details: BSTU, (A-82/17); Base University

Authors: Yadigaroglu G.
Title: Computational Fluid Dynamics for nuclear applications: From CFD to multi-scale CMFD
Affiliations: Swiss Fed. Inst. of Technol.-Zurich, Nuclear Engineering Laboratory, ETH-Zentrum, CLT CH-8092 Zurich, S., Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Yadigaroglu G., Swiss Fed. Inst. of Technol.-Zurich, Nuclear Engineering Laboratory, ETH-Zentrum, CLT CH-8092 Zurich, S., Switzerland
Abstract: New trends in computational methods for nuclear reactor thermal-hydraulics are discussed; traditionally, these have been based on the two-fluid model. Although CFD computations for single phase flows are commonplace, Computational Multi-Fluid Dynamics (CMFD) is still under development. One-fluid methods coupled with interface tracking techniques provide interesting opportunities and enlarge the scope of problems that can be solved. For certain problems, one may have to conduct "cascades" of computations at increasingly finer scales to resolve all issues. The case study of condensation of steam/air mixtures injected from a downward-facing vent into a pool of water and a proposed CMFD initiative to numerically model Critical Heat Flux (CHF) illustrate such cascades. For the venting problem, a variety of tools are used: a system code for system behaviour; an interface-tracking method (Volume of Fluid, VOF) to examine the behaviour of large bubbles; direct-contact condensation can be treated either by Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) or by analytical methods. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Computational fluid dynamics; Computational methods; Computer simulation; Correlation methods; Heat flux; Large scale systems; Nuclear energy; Problem solving; Thermoanalysis; Velocity measurement; Computational multi-fluid dynamics (CMFD); Drift-flux models; Interface-tracking methods; Light water reactors (LWR); Nuclear engineering

Title: Computing moment-based probability tables for self-shielding calculations in lattice codes
Affiliations: Centre d'Etudes de Saclay, Commissariat a l'Energie Atom., LENR/SERMA/DM2S/DEN, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Hébert A., Centre d'Etudes de Saclay, Commissariat a l'Energie Atom., LENR/SERMA/DM2S/DEN, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, France; Coste M., Centre d'Etudes de Saclay, Commissariat a l'Energie Atom., LENR/SERMA/DM2S/DEN, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, France
Abstract: As part of the self-shielding model used in the APOLLO2 lattice code, probability tables are required to compute self-shielded cross sections for coarse energy groups (typically with 99 or 172 groups). This paper describes the replacement of the multiband tables (typically with 51 subgroups) with moment-based tables in release 2.5 of APOLLO2. An improved Ribon method is proposed to compute moment-based probability tables, allowing important savings in CPU resources while maintaining the accuracy of the self-shielding algorithm. Finally, a validation is presented where the absorption rates obtained with each of these techniques are compared with exact values obtained using a fine-group elastic slowing-down calculation in the resolved energy domain. Other results, relative to the Rowland's benchmark and to three assembly production cases, are also presented.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Mathematical models; Method of moments; Monte Carlo methods; Nuclear energy; Probability; Lattice codes; Probability tables; Ribon method; Software package CESCOL; Nuclear engineering

Authors: Gomez Fernandez M.; Tokuhiro A.; Welter K.; Wu Q.
Author full names: Gomez Fernandez, Mario (56423565900); Tokuhiro, Akira (55523868700); Welter, Kent (55963563100); Wu, Qiao (7404601900)
Title: Nuclear energy system's behavior and decision making using machine learning
Affiliations: School of Nuclear Science and Engineering, Oregon State University, 100 Radiation Center, Corvallis, 97330, OR, United States; Energy Systems and Nuclear Science Research Centre, University of Ontario Institute of Technology, Room 4036, 2000 Simcoe Street North, Oshawa, L1H 7K4, ON, Canada; NuScale Power, LLC, 1100 NE Circle Boulevard, Suite 200, Corvallis, 97330, OR, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gomez Fernandez M., School of Nuclear Science and Engineering, Oregon State University, 100 Radiation Center, Corvallis, 97330, OR, United States, NuScale Power, LLC, 1100 NE Circle Boulevard, Suite 200, Corvallis, 97330, OR, United States; Tokuhiro A., Energy Systems and Nuclear Science Research Centre, University of Ontario Institute of Technology, Room 4036, 2000 Simcoe Street North, Oshawa, L1H 7K4, ON, Canada; Welter K., NuScale Power, LLC, 1100 NE Circle Boulevard, Suite 200, Corvallis, 97330, OR, United States; Wu Q., School of Nuclear Science and Engineering, Oregon State University, 100 Radiation Center, Corvallis, 97330, OR, United States
Abstract: Early versions of artificial neural networks’ ability to learn from data based on multivariable statistics and optimization demanded high computational performance as multiple training iterations are necessary to find an optimal local minimum. The rapid advancements in computational performance, storage capacity, and big data management have allowed machine-learning techniques to improve in the areas of learning speed, non-linear data handling, and complex features identification. Machine-learning techniques have proven successful and been used in the areas of autonomous machines, speech recognition, and natural language processing. Though the application of artificial intelligence in the nuclear engineering domain has been limited, it has accurately predicted desired outcomes in some instances and has proven to be a worthwhile area of research. The objectives of this study are to create neural networks topologies to use Oregon State University's Multi-Application Small Light Water Reactor integrated test facility's data and evaluate its capability of predicting the systems behavior during various core power inputs and a loss of flow accident. This study uses data from multiple sensors, focusing primarily on the reactor pressure vessel and its internal components. As a result, the artificial neural networks are able to predict the behavior of the system with good accuracy in each scenario. Its ability to provide technical data can help decision makers to take actions more rapidly, identify safety issues, or provide an intelligent system with the potential of using pattern recognition for reactor accident identification and classification. Overall, the development and application of neural networks can be promising in the nuclear industry and any product processes that can benefit from utilizing a quick data analysis tool. © 2017 The Authors

Authors: Iborra A.; Caceres D.A.; Ortiz F.J.; Franco J.P.; Palma P.S.; Alvarez B.
Author full names: Iborra, Andrés (6603847183); Caceres, Diego Alonso (26430524200); Ortiz, Francisco J. (55248561000); Franco, Juan Pastor (26636367700); Palma, Pedro Sánchez (14034637300); Alvarez, Bárbara (7005773328)
Title: Design of service robots: Experiences using software engineering
Affiliations: Electronics Technology Department, Technical University of Cartagena, Cartagena, Spain; Universidad Politécnica de Cartagena, Cartagena, Spain; Technical University of Cartagena, Cartagena, Spain; Technical University of Valencia, Valencia, Spain; Technical University of Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Universidad Politécnica de Cartagena, División de Sistemas e Ingeniería Electrónica (DSIE), Cartagena E-30202, Campus Muralla del Mar s/n, Spain

Abstract: According to the International Federation of Robotics (IFR), "a service robot is a robot which operates semi or fully autonomously to perform services useful to the well being of human and equipment, excluding manufacturing operations" [1]. These devices are typically complex systems requiring the input of knowledge from numerous disciplines. The authors have been using different software engineering techniques for the last 15 years, integrating new paradigms in the service robot development process as they emerged. This has made it possible to achieve rapid development of applications and subsequent maintenance. During the early years (1993-1998), our effortswere directed at the development of software for various kinds of teleoperated robots to performmaintenance tasks in nuclear power plants [2]; during a second phase (1999-2006),we built applications for ship-hull cleaning robots [3]. All this time, we have been applying all the possibilities of software engineering, from the use of paradigms for structured and object-based programming in early developments to the adoption of the current model-driven approach [model-driven engineering (MDE)] [4]. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Kennedy R.P.
Title: Performance-goal based (risk informed) approach for establishing the SSE site specific response spectrum for future nuclear power plants
Affiliations: RPK Structural Mechanics Consulting, Escondido, CA 92026, 28625 Mountain Meadow Road, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kennedy R.P., RPK Structural Mechanics Consulting, Escondido, CA 92026, 28625 Mountain Meadow Road, United States
Abstract: This paper provides the technical basis for the performance-goal based approach presented in the American Society of Civil Engineering Standard ASCE/SEI 43-05 for establishing the safe shutdown earthquake (SSE) site specific design response spectrum (SSRS) for future nuclear power plants. This approach has been adopted by the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) in their Regulatory Guide 1.208. This approach has now been followed at more than 20 sites. In addition to more thoroughly documenting the basis for the ASCE 43-05 performance-goal based approach, the paper also summarizes the minimum seismic core damage frequency (SCDF) achieved at 28 Central and Eastern U.S. sites when the SSRS is defined by this approach coupled with other NRC requirements. The minimum SCDF lies in the range of less than 6 × 10-6/yr to 0.6 × 10-6/yr with a median ratio of about 3 × 10 -6/yr. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Civil engineering; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Optimization; Plant shutdowns; American Society of Civil Engineering; Core damage frequency; Regulatory guides; Response spectra; Site-specific; Site-specific response spectrum; U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission; Core disruptive accidents

Authors: Kumar M.; Whittaker A.S.; Constantinou M.C.
Author full names: Kumar, Manish (57216607701); Whittaker, Andrew S. (7102570719); Constantinou, Michael C. (35578378900)
Title: Experimental investigation of cavitation in elastomeric seismic isolation bearings
Affiliations: Department of Civil, Structural and Environmental Engineering, University at Buffalo, State University of New York, 212 Ketter Hall, Buffalo, 14260, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kumar M., Department of Civil, Structural and Environmental Engineering, University at Buffalo, State University of New York, 212 Ketter Hall, Buffalo, 14260, NY, United States; Whittaker A.S., Department of Civil, Structural and Environmental Engineering, University at Buffalo, State University of New York, 212 Ketter Hall, Buffalo, 14260, NY, United States; Constantinou M.C., Department of Civil, Structural and Environmental Engineering, University at Buffalo, State University of New York, 212 Ketter Hall, Buffalo, 14260, NY, United States
Abstract: Design standards for seismic isolation of nuclear power plants in USA will consider the effects of beyond design basis loadings, including extreme earthquakes. Seismic isolation is being considered for new build nuclear power plant construction and design of isolation systems will have to consider these extreme loadings, which includes the possibility of net tensile force in bearings under beyond design basis shaking. A series of experiments were conducted at University at Buffalo to characterize the behavior of elastomeric bearings in tension. Sixteen low damping rubber bearings from two manufacturers, with similar geometric properties but different shear moduli, were tested under various loading conditions to determine factors that affect cavitation in an elastomeric bearing. The effect of cavitation on the shear and axial properties of elastomeric bearings was investigated by performing post-cavitation tests. The test data were used to validate a phenomenological model of an elastomeric bearing in tension, which is implemented in OpenSees, ABAQUS and LS-DYNA. © 2015 Elsevier Ltd.

Authors: Yan S.; Tran C.C.; Chen Y.; Tan K.; Habiyaremye J.L.
Author full names: Yan, Shengyuan (7401744904); Tran, Cong Chi (57194972351); Chen, Yu (55721196200); Tan, Ke (57085694800); Habiyaremye, Jean Luc (57194977746)
Title: Effect of user interface layout on the operators’ mental workload in emergency operating procedures in nuclear power plants
Affiliations: College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, 150001, Heilongjiang, China; College of Mechanical Engineering, Heilongjiang University of Science & Technology, Harbin, 150022, Heilongjiang, China; China Nuclear Power Engineering Co Ltd, Shenzhen, 518000, Guangdong, China
Authors with affiliations: Yan S., College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, 150001, Heilongjiang, China; Tran C.C., College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, 150001, Heilongjiang, China; Chen Y., College of Mechanical Engineering, Heilongjiang University of Science & Technology, Harbin, 150022, Heilongjiang, China; Tan K., China Nuclear Power Engineering Co Ltd, Shenzhen, 518000, Guangdong, China; Habiyaremye J.L., College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, 150001, Heilongjiang, China
Abstract: The improved control interface designs in nuclear power plants (NPPs) have been constantly developed in order to satisfy actual requirements. In this article, the effect of user interface layout on mental workload (MWL) of operators in emergency operating procedures in NPPs is analyzed. The control circuit interface of the Chemical and Volume Control system (RCV) was redesigned based on some human factor criterions and it was compared to the original interface during the procedure of system boots. The multi-index evaluation method based on performance measures (i.e., time to complete and error rate), subjective rating (i.e., NASA Task Load Index (NASA-TLX)) and physiological measure (i.e., eye movement) was used to evaluate MWL of operators. Twenty-two engineering students tested both interfaces in randomized order. The results showed that interface design has a significant effect on operators’ MWL. Specifically, the redesigned interface was rated significantly lower in overall workload, time to complete, and fixation indices, but higher blink rate. The results suggested that human factor criterions have a significant effect on operators’ MWL so they should be considered during designing of interface, and using of NASA-TLX tool and eye movement technique is useful for assessing of human-computer interface (HCI) designs in NPPs. © 2017
Author Keywords: Eye-tracking; Mental workload; NASA-TLX; Nuclear power plants; User interface

Authors: Thai D.-K.; Kim S.-E.
Title: Safety assessment of a nuclear power plant building subjected to an aircraft crash
Affiliations: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Sejong University, 98 Gunja-dong, Gwangjin-ku, Seoul, 143-747, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Thai D.-K., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Sejong University, 98 Gunja-dong, Gwangjin-ku, Seoul, 143-747, South Korea; Kim S.-E., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Sejong University, 98 Gunja-dong, Gwangjin-ku, Seoul, 143-747, South Korea
Abstract: This paper presents a safety assessment of a nuclear building subjected to an aircraft crash using numerical analysis. For impact simulation, the reinforced concrete (RC) Primary Auxiliary Building (PAB) of the Korea Standard Nuclear Power Plant (KSNP) is fully modeled and an aircraft model of a Boeing 767-400 is used. The Riera function is used to verify the analysis result of impact force-time history. The IRIS test is used to verify the structural behavior of the RC wall under impact loading. The safety assessment of the building is performed with regard to different impact scenarios. The safety of the nuclear building under aircraft crash, including (1) global structural safety, (2) local structural safety, and (3) vibration safety are evaluated and discussed. The results show that the global and local structural safety of the PAB is ensured in all impact scenarios. However, the vibration safety of the building is not ensured. In accordance, the regulatory guide of United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission (U.S. NRC), shutdown of the nuclear power plant is required. © 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aircraft accidents; Buildings; Crashworthiness; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Plant shutdowns; Reinforced concrete; Safety engineering; Global structural safety; Impact simulation; Korea Standard Nuclear Power Plants; Power plant buildings; Regulatory guides; Safety assessments; Structural behaviors; United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission (U.S. NRC); Fighter aircraft

Authors: Kaiser P.K.; Zou D.; Lang P.A.
Title: Stress determination by back-analysis of excavation-induced stress changes - a case study
Affiliations: Geomechanics Research Centre, Laurentian University, Sudbury, Ontario, Canada; Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., Whiteshell Nuclear Research Establishment, Pinawa, Manitoba, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kaiser P.K., Geomechanics Research Centre, Laurentian University, Sudbury, Ontario, Canada; Zou D., Geomechanics Research Centre, Laurentian University, Sudbury, Ontario, Canada; Lang P.A., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., Whiteshell Nuclear Research Establishment, Pinawa, Manitoba, Canada
Abstract: An Underground Research Laboratory (URL) has been constructed by Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) to study various aspects of disposing of nuclear fuel waste in the Canadian Shield. In order to ensure good quality and long life of the construction, one important factor to be considered is the in situ stress field. As part of the research program, stress changes have been measured during the advance of a tunnel to monitor the stress response to excavation. It is desirable to estimate the state of in situ stress from these stress change measurements and to compare the results with overcoring data. This paper describes the application of a recently developed stress change fitting technique for stress determination. The basic principle and the fitting procedure are briefly summarized and the back-analysis process for the data collected at the URL is presented in detail. A boundary element model was used to predict the stress changes as required by the fitting approach. This new method of in situ stress determination was successfully applied in this case. The back-analyzed stresses agree very well with those determined from overcoring tests. The quality of individual measurements was assessed and the required minimum number of measurements for a conclusive data interpretation is evaluated. © 1990 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: Excavation - Stresses; Hazardous Materials - Waste Disposal; Research Laboratories - Underground; Rock Mechanics; Stresses - Analysis; Canada; In Situ Stress Determination; Nuclear Engineering; Tunnels; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Finkler H.; Schirra M.
Title: Transformation behaviour of the high temperature martensitic steels with 8 - 14% chromium
Affiliations: Mat. Devmt. Operations Department, Saarstahl, Völklingen, Germany; Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Inst. für Materialforschung I, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Finkler H., Mat. Devmt. Operations Department, Saarstahl, Völklingen, Germany; Schirra M., Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Inst. für Materialforschung I, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: Comprehensive development work on martensitic steels belonging to the so-called 12% Cr steel group were performed at the Institute for Materials Research (IMF) of Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe on martensitic steels, the so-called 12% Cr steel group, in order to meet the various requirements in nuclear and conventional energy technology. The transformation characteristics of 29 different grades of steel and 38 heats have been determined and continuous cooling transformation (CCT) diagrams have been prepared. The diagrams are first described by groups of subjects in a chronological order because the change in the chemical composition cannot be correlated in all cases with the change in transformation behaviour. The quenching hardness can be satisfactorily described as a function of the C+N content if, taking into account the Nb, Zr, Ta, Hf fractions, a common effectiveness factor is calculated. This effectiveness factor is also integrated in the calculation of the Ms point by modifying accordingly the equation proposed by Steven and Haynes for low-alloy steels and supplemented by the summands for V and W. An equation is introduced for the calculation of the critical cooling rate for pearlite transformation which takes into account the special influence exerted by elements Cr, V, Mo, W, Ge. The comparison between calculated and measured values for Ms and Vcrit is satisfactory, except for some steels.
Index Keywords: Calculations; Chromium; Composition; Cooling; Hardness; Heat treatment; High temperature properties; Nuclear engineering; Pearlitic transformations; Phase diagrams; Quenching; Steel; Cooling rate; Martensitic steel; Martensitic transformations

Authors: Nisan S.; Benzarti N.
Title: A comprehensive economic evaluation of integrated desalination systems using fossil fuelled and nuclear energies and including their environmental costs
Affiliations: Directorate of Nuclear Energy (DEN), Reactor Studies Department (DER), Innovative Systems Service (SESI), F-13108 Saint Paul-lez-Durance, France; University of Grenoble, Grenoble, France
Authors with affiliations: Nisan S., Directorate of Nuclear Energy (DEN), Reactor Studies Department (DER), Innovative Systems Service (SESI), F-13108 Saint Paul-lez-Durance, France; Benzarti N., University of Grenoble, Grenoble, France
Abstract: Seawater desalination is now widely accepted as an attractive alternative source of freshwater for domestic and industrial uses. Despite the considerable progress made in the relevant technologies desalination, however, remains an energy intensive process in which the energy cost is the paramount factor. This study is a first of a kind in that we have integrated the environmental costs into the power and desalination costs. The study has focused on the seawater desalination cost evaluation of the following systems. It is supposed that they will be operating in the co-generation mode (simultaneous production of electrical power and desalted water) in 2015: Fossil fuelled based systems such as the coal and oil fired plants and the gas turbine combined cycle plant, coupled to MED, and RO; Pressurised water reactors such as the PWR-900 and the AP-600, coupled to MED, and RO; High temperature reactors such as the GT-MHR, the PBMR, coupled to MED, with the utilisation of virtually free waste-heat provided by these reactors. The study is made in real site-specific conditions of a site in Southern Europe. Sensitivity studies for different parameters such as the fossil fuel prices, interest and discount rates, power costs etc., have also been undertaken. The results obtained are then used to evaluate the financial interest of selected integrated desalination systems in terms of a detailed cash flow analysis, providing the net present values, pay back periods and the internal rate of returns. Analysis of the results shows that among the fossil fuelled systems the power and desalination costs by circulating fluidized bed coal fired plant would be the lowest with current coal prices. Those by oil fired plants would be highest. In all cases, integrated nuclear energy systems would lead to considerably lower power and water costs than the corresponding coal based systems. When external costs for different energies are internalised in power and water costs, the relative cost differences are considerably increased in favour of the nuclear systems. Financial analysis further confirms these conclusions. © 2008.
Author Keywords: Economics; Nuclear desalination

Authors: Holdren John P.; Berwald D.H.; Budnitz Robert J.; Crocker Jimmy G.; Delene J.G.; Endicott Ron D.; Kazimi Mujid S.; Krakowski R.A.; Logan B.Grant; Schultz Kenneth R.
Author full names: Holdren, John P. (7004010723); Berwald, D.H. (7003831147); Budnitz, Robert J. (6603710575); Crocker, Jimmy G. (7102623556); Delene, J.G. (6602333782); Endicott, Ron D. (6602774331); Kazimi, Mujid S. (7006908656); Krakowski, R.A. (7005836239); Logan, B.Grant (7202196565); Schultz, Kenneth R. (7202350825)
Title: EXPLORING THE COMPETITIVE POTENTIAL OF MAGNETIC FUSION ENERGY: THE INTERACTION OF ECONOMICS WITH SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHARACTERISTICS.
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Holdren John P., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Berwald D.H., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Budnitz Robert J., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Crocker Jimmy G., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Delene J.G., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Endicott Ron D., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Kazimi Mujid S., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Krakowski R.A., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Logan B.Grant, Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA; Schultz Kenneth R., Univ of California, Berkeley,, Berkeley, CA, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: MFE systems have the potential to achieve costs of electricity comparable to those of present and future fission systems, coupled with significant safety and environmental advantages. This conclusion is based on (a) assumptions about plasma performance and engineering characteristics that are optimistic but defensible extrapolations from current experience, and (b) consistent application of an elaborate set of engineering/economic and safety/environment models to a range of fusion and fission reference cases, with the known characteristics of fission light water reactors as a benchmark. Economic competitiveness depends on attaining plasma and engineering performances that are not yet assured. Achieving the potential environmental and safety advantages depends in large measure on designs specifically tailored to do so and on the use of low-activation materials whose practicality for fusion applications remains to be demonstrated. It is essential that sufficient research and development be devoted early to determining which of a variety of confinement schemes, structural materials, blanket types, and fuel cycle/energy conversion combinations can actually be made practical.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; ECONOMICS - Analysis; NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Economics; TOKAMAK DEVICES - Environmental Impact; FUSION ENERGY ECONOMICS; MAGNETIC FUSION ENERGY; SAFETY ANALYSIS; Nuclear energy

Authors: Lattin W.C.; Utgikar V.P.
Author full names: Lattin, William C. (15832155800); Utgikar, Vivek P. (6507720461)
Title: Global warming potential of the sulfur-iodine process using life cycle assessment methodology
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID 83402, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID 83402, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lattin W.C., Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID 83402, United States; Utgikar V.P., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID 83402, United States
Abstract: A life cycle assessment (LCA) of one proposed method of hydrogen production - thermochemical water-splitting using the sulfur-iodine cycle couple with a very high-temperature nuclear reactor - is presented in this paper. Thermochemical water-splitting theoretically offers a higher overall efficiency than high-temperature electrolysis of water because heat from the nuclear reactor is provided directly to the hydrogen generation process, instead of using the intermediate step of generating electricity. The primary heat source for the S-I cycle is an advanced nuclear reactor operating at temperatures corresponding to those required by the sulfur-iodine process. This LCA examines the environmental impact of the combined advanced nuclear and hydrogen generation plants and focuses on quantifying the emissions of carbon dioxide per kilogram of hydrogen produced. The results are presented in terms of global warming potential (GWP). The GWP of the system is 2500 g carbon dioxide-equivalent (CO2-eq) per kilogram of hydrogen produced. The GWP of this process is approximately one-sixth of that for hydrogen production by steam reforming of natural gas, and is comparable to producing hydrogen from wind- or hydro-electric conventional electrolysis. © 2008 International Association for Hydrogen Energy.

Authors: Nayak A.K.; Dubey P.; Chavan D.N.; Vijayan P.K.
Title: Study on the stability behaviour of two-phase natural circulation systems using a four-equation drift flux model
Affiliations: Reactor Engineering Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai, 400085, Trombay, India; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Dr. B.A. Technological University, Lonere 402103, Raigad, Maharashtra, India
Authors with affiliations: Nayak A.K., Reactor Engineering Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai, 400085, Trombay, India; Dubey P., Reactor Engineering Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai, 400085, Trombay, India; Chavan D.N., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Dr. B.A. Technological University, Lonere 402103, Raigad, Maharashtra, India; Vijayan P.K., Reactor Engineering Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai, 400085, Trombay, India
Abstract: Theoretical investigations were carried out to study the influence of two-phase flow parameters such as friction factor multiplier, drift velocity and void distribution parameter on the stability of boiling two-phase natural circulation systems. The theoretical model considers a four-equation drift flux model which solves the linearised conservation equations of mass, momentum and energy applicable to boiling two-phase natural circulation systems. The model was applied to three boiling natural circulation loops wherein Type I and Type II instabilities were observed over a wide range of operating pressures. The two-phase friction loss was predicted using different friction factor multiplier models available in literature. It was found that these models influence the steady state and threshold powers for stability, especially the Type II instabilities in natural circulation significantly. Since the void fraction depends on the drift velocity and the void distribution parameter in two-phase flow, these parameters were varied and their effects on the natural circulation flow stability were investigated. It was found that an increase in either the drift velocity or the void distribution parameter reduces the unstable regions observed in the Type I or Type II flow instabilities in two-phase natural circulation systems. Further, investigations were carried out to study the effect of loop diameter on the Type I and Type II instabilities in natural circulation. This study is important to reveal the capability of the reduced diameter scaled facilities of the prototype systems to simulate natural circulation instabilities. The results indicate that with increase in the loop diameter, the threshold power of the Type I instability and the Type II instability increases. Moreover, the stability of natural circulation greatly enhances with increase in the diameter of the loop. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Naserbegi A.; Aghaie M.; Minuchehr A.; Alahyarizadeh G.
Author full names: Naserbegi, A. (57200497776); Aghaie, M. (57032383500); Minuchehr, A. (14048836000); Alahyarizadeh, Gh (37461143600)
Title: A novel exergy optimization of Bushehr nuclear power plant by gravitational search algorithm (GSA)
Affiliations: Engineering Department, Shahid Beheshti University, G.C, P.O.Box, Tehran, 1983963113, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Naserbegi A., Engineering Department, Shahid Beheshti University, G.C, P.O.Box, Tehran, 1983963113, Iran; Aghaie M., Engineering Department, Shahid Beheshti University, G.C, P.O.Box, Tehran, 1983963113, Iran; Minuchehr A., Engineering Department, Shahid Beheshti University, G.C, P.O.Box, Tehran, 1983963113, Iran; Alahyarizadeh G., Engineering Department, Shahid Beheshti University, G.C, P.O.Box, Tehran, 1983963113, Iran
Abstract: In recent years metaheuristic optimization algorithms have been widely developed. These algorithms are inspired from nature for solving complicated engineering problems. In this work, gravitational search algorithm (GSA) based on Newton's law of gravity is introduced for exergy optimization of the Bushehr nuclear power plant (BNPP). The main objective in this work is to minimize exergy destruction in the BNPP. In this analysis, beside the GSA, Genetic Algorithm (GA) is applied and the performances of these algorithms in two different cases are compared. In first case, the sphere function as a challenging optimization problem is investigated and it is demonstrated that the GSA has reliable fitness values (3.7602e-17). In the next case, the exergy destruction of the BNPP is studied and the exergy efficiencies of all components in the BNPP are evaluated. The reactor core (pressure vessel) and steam generator with 1511.35 MWth and 146.65 MWth of exergy destructions and irreversibility ratios of 50.34% and 4.88%, are introduced as the main irreversible components, respectively. The exergy destruction in the BNPP with the application of the GSA and GA is minimized and the optimum operating parameters in desired streams are reported. The exergy destruction of the BNPP (1968.95 MWth) is minimized to 1965.9 MWth. The results indicate the effectiveness of the GSA and it is shown that the method has robust high-quality solution for exergy destruction optimization. © 2018 Elsevier Ltd

Authors: Lee D.; Seong P.H.; Kim J.
Author full names: Lee, Daeil (57191924845); Seong, Poong Hyun (7003752173); Kim, Jonghyun (55670982500)
Title: Autonomous operation algorithm for safety systems of nuclear power plants by using long-short term memory and function-based hierarchical framework
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear Engineering, Chosun University, 309 Pilmun-daero, Dong-gu, Gwangju, 501-709, South Korea; Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 291 Daehak-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon, 34141, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee D., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Chosun University, 309 Pilmun-daero, Dong-gu, Gwangju, 501-709, South Korea; Seong P.H., Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 291 Daehak-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon, 34141, South Korea; Kim J., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Chosun University, 309 Pilmun-daero, Dong-gu, Gwangju, 501-709, South Korea
Abstract: With the improvement of computer performance and the emergence of cutting-edge artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms, an autonomous operation based on AI is being applied to many industries. An autonomous algorithm is a higher-level concept than conventional automatic operation in nuclear power plants (NPPs). In order to achieve autonomous operation, the autonomous algorithm needs to include superior functions to monitor, control and diagnose automated subsystems. This study suggests an autonomous operation algorithm for NPP safety systems using a function-based hierarchical framework (FHF) and a long short-term memory (LSTM). The FHF hierarchically models the safety goals, functions, systems, and components in the NPP. Then, the hierarchical structure is transformed into an LSTM network that is an evolutionary version of a recurrent neural network. This approach is applied to a reference NPP, a Westinghouse 930 MWe, three-loop pressurized water reactor. This LSTM network has been trained and validated using a compact nuclear simulator. © 2018 Elsevier Ltd

Authors: Kochunas B.; Huan X.
Title: Digital twin concepts with uncertainty for nuclear power applications
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear Engineering and Radiological Sciences, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48109, MI, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48109, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kochunas B., Department of Nuclear Engineering and Radiological Sciences, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48109, MI, United States; Huan X., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48109, MI, United States
Abstract: Digital Twins (DTs) are receiving considerable attention from multiple disciplines. Much of the literature at this time is dedicated to the conceptualization of digital twins, and associated enabling technologies and challenges. In this paper, we consider these propositions for the specific application of nuclear power. Our review finds that the current DT concepts are amenable to nuclear power systems, but benefit from some modifications and enhancements. Further, some areas of the existing modeling and simulation infrastructure around nuclear power systems are adaptable to DT development, while more recent efforts in advanced modeling and simulation are less suitable at this time. For nuclear power applications, DT development should rely first on mechanistic model-based methods to leverage the extensive experience and understanding of these systems. Model-free techniques can then be adopted to selectively, and correctively, augment limitations in the model-based approaches. Challenges to the realization of a DT are also discussed, with some being unique to nuclear engineering, however most are broader. A challenging aspect we discuss in detail for DTs is the incorporation of uncertainty quantification (UQ). Forward UQ enables the propagation of uncertainty from the digital representations to predict behavior of the physical asset. Similarly, inverse UQ allows for the incorporation of data from new measurements obtained from the physical asset back into the DT. Optimization under uncertainty facilitates decision support through the formal methods of optimal experimental design and design optimization that maximize information gain, or performance, of the physical asset in an uncertain environment. © 2021 by the authors. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
Author Keywords: Digital twin; Nuclear power; Uncertainty quantification
Index Keywords: Decision support systems; Digital twin; Formal methods; Inverse problems; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Digital representations; Enabling technologies; Model based approach; Optimal experimental designs; Optimization under uncertainty; Propagation of uncertainties; Uncertain environments; Uncertainty quantifications; Nuclear power plants
